column2: @AdamSinger Imagine if we put the entire military budget into developing the best gamers.

They should be the size and weight of a refrigerator and maybe double as a literal safe. Really drive home the point that self custody is important.

Wondering about if it's possible to track instances of specific opinions on reddit, including frequency of times that opinion is expressed, and where. Eventually being able to track back to where an opinion originated, took root, and spread.
Like "oh shit, sorry bro I didn't mean to steal YOUR apes. Here, have 5 of them back. Here's 50E as an apology."

Crypto opens up some extremely interesting dynamics like hackers choosing to give back portions of what they stole to specific people they stole from.

The ease of transacting exactly how and when you decide makes this extremely easy to do even while actively exploiting.

Imagine being at a party full of nerds but not really knowing anything about crypto or NFTs and then all of a sudden you see a mass exodus of all the nerds leaving the party checking phones and freaking out for some inexplicable reason.
Metaverses are just the information bubbles you're in.
The real blockchain social graph is going to just be everyone's tracking of wallets which they monitor specifically to avoid the things that wallet invests in.

*before you even get the chance to talk to someone

It's kinda crazy that in the process of buying something like a home service, you could potentially go through 2-3+ different auctions before you even talk to somebody.

- Google ads auction
- Leadgen site auctions your data to high bidder
- Bidder who buys may run own auction

The worst part about millennials/humans is that we want every newly proposed solution to be absolutely perfect.

It takes being on the other side of a solution to see that solving a portion of the problem now is better than never solving it, but always complaining about it.

@web3rambo Agreed. But that feels...dangerous, kind of? Like taking the fun out of it or taking yourself too seriously for some creators. But also definitely see that mentality working well for many others.

Responsibility as in when creating & selling something you're taking on the burden of people potentially looking to you for their financial gain.

@MidCapNFT Agreed. I'm always torn by now much I want the space to grow, and how not really ready for growth it is.
It's not just crypto, either. These dynamics play out in startups too, but to a lesser extent.

Crypto scams exist because crypto itself isn't mature enough. It's still relatively easy to get your hands on large amounts. In that environment scams thrive. As crypto adoption increases, scams increase, then fade as it becomes more difficult to acquire larger amounts.
"could they not just..." is one of the most intellectually lazy ways of thinking yet also one of the most common formats on twitter

imo a lot of the crazy swings we see in crypto are really just spikes in excitement about a project and excitement dwindling/sustaining over time.

If regular startups had shares available to the public from day 1 of their launch we'd see similar volatility in those shares.

@adamscochran I wonder if a system could work where your staking rewards are locked and only unlock if you vote in XX% of proposals over a pre-specified timeframe.

Could potentially encourage ppl voting who don't really care, but that can already happen anyway.
